results.title: Smile of Buddha
results.creator_credit: Yves Gautier, UNICEF and Office de Radiodiffusion Television Francais
results.brief_description: The sparrows of Saigon of the opening song refer to the thousands of homeless and injured children of this city, who are both victims of the war or whose already miserable condition the war has worsened. Orphanages and hospitals provide some of these children with food and care. Various nurses and organisers in these places, speak about the children, their work, and children are shown as they talk, play or are treated.

results.title: Smile for auntie
results.creator_credit: Gene Deitch, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: A gently wicked satiric animated look at an aunt’s attempt to make baby smile. About the strange behaviour adults indulge in when attempting to communicate with, and relate to an infant. The aunt is seen from a child’s eye view. From the book written and illustrated by Diane Paterson. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Smash palace
results.creator_credit: Roger Donaldson, New Zealand Film Commission and Aardvark Films
results.brief_description: Smash Palace is a remarkable drama about a marital breakup which erupts into an impulsive kidnapping of a child by the father, and a totally credible escalation to the brink of tragedy. Bruno Lawrence and Anna Jemison play the estranged couple in strong performances. Filmed amongst a vast junk-yard of cars, Donaldson’s direction is economical and enthralling, capturing the tension that goes beneath the surface of this all too real drama.

results.title: Smart footwork
results.creator_credit: Toby Carpenter, Palfreeman Film Productions and Renown Pictures
results.brief_description: It is said that a man spends half of his life in his shoes, yet gives them less thought than any other article of apparel. Here in this film we watch the process of manufacture of footwear in a British factory, starting with the evil-smelling tannery where the hides are treated, and ending wiht someone’s feet in a smart pair of finished shoes. The film shows also examples of footwear worn as long ago as the 15th century, and watch master craftsmen at work on hand-made shoes.

results.title: Smallpox: merciless traveller
results.creator_credit: Vaclav Bedrich, World Health Organisation and Czechoslovak Film Studios
results.brief_description: This animated film deals with the history of smallpox throughout the ages. Shows how it has ravaged the world from the time of the Pharoahs, the discovery of a vaccine by Edward Jenner and his fight to have it recognised by international medical authorities and how the smallpox problem is being dealt with in the present day.

results.title: Small world = Le Monde est petit
results.creator_credit: Jacques Valentin, Unesco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Children from some forty countries were asked to give their interpretation in drawings of the world from pre-history to the year 3000 AD. This film, made within the framework of UNESCO’s project for the mutual understanding of Orient and Occident, shows that the imagination of children knows no frontiers.

results.title: Small towns, big picture: a journey in building community
results.creator_credit: Image Link, Judy Spokes, Philip Ashton and Maureen Rogers
results.brief_description:
Five country towns in Central Victoria - Dunolly,
Wedderburn, Carisbrook, Maldon and Talbot - have been
involved in a social experimental project called “Small Towns Big Picture” for the last two years or more with the
Centre for Sustainable Regional Communities, La Trobe
University, Bendigo under the leadership of Dr Maureen
Rogers. Concern was being expressed about the demise of small country towns and their future, economically,
socially and environmentally and the main intention of the
Project was to develop a toolkit for measuring the “health” of a community - a benchmark for sustainability. With the assistance of Judy Spokes and the Cultural Development Network seven artists were commissioned to work with the communities and the researchers. Workshops were established incorporating the community, including the Energy Footprint Project and a Community Cohesion Project. Craig Christie (playwright) has been working on creating and producing a musical play in Carisbrook capturing the issues from the Community Cohesion focus group and auditioning the local
communities to perform in the play. This documentary
provides an inside view of the workings of “Small Towns Big Picture” and includes interviews with artists, project
leaders, councillors, teachers and members of the
community.

results.title: Small soldiers
results.creator_credit: Joe Dante, Michael Finnell, Colin Wilson, NBCUniversal and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: When defence industry firm Globotech takes over the small toy company Heartland Play Systems, it makes for some interesting merging of ideas. New CEO Gil Mars (Denis Leary) approves an enhancement to current action figures to make them look more realistic, and gives the task to Heartland employees Larry Benson (Jay Mohr) and Irwin Wayfair (David Cross). This results in the creation of some serious looking fighting figures, appropriately called the Command Elite who wage a constant war against the alien Gorgonites. As a final measure, Benson inserts some of Globotech’s powerful military computer chips into the new toys. In a run down toy store in Ohio, a father and son get to see the new product and decide it’s just what they need to boost their failing business. The son learns to communicate with the leader of the Gorgonites, Archer (voice supplied by Frank Langella), which has serious consequences for their future. It’s not long before the Command Elite burst forth from their packing, led by Chip Hazard (voice supplied by Tommy Lee Jones), ready as ever to do battle with the Gorgonites. When Chip sees the Gorgonite leader communicating with humans, it results in an all out war between the Command Elite and humans in a fantastic mix of live action, animatronics, puppetry and computer animation. Voices from Robert Aldrich’s ‘The Dirty Dozen’ are provided as some of the voices of the Command Elite. Cast also includes Kirsten Dunst and Gregory Smith. Features a tribute to Phil Hartman after the closing credits.

results.title: Small smoke at Blaze Creek
results.creator_credit: Michael Scott, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Forest fire in mountainous British Columbia, as experienced by the men who must try to quench it from the air and at close quarters on the ground. Over half of fire outbreaks occur through carelessness, and this film affords a close, vivid view of the result: a whole mountainside turned into a searing, crackling holocaust until nothing remains but grey, desolate waste—mute reproach to all who travel or work in the forests. (Awards: Berlin; Belgrade.)
